text: - [Ruth] Hello, my name is Ruth

and I am your AI voiceover
companion for this video.

Today I'm going to show
you how to operationalize

your AWS WAF logs with
Amazon Security Lake.

Amazon Security Lake recently
announced the expansion
and log coverage support for AWS
Web Application Firewall logs.

This video will show you how
to operationalize AWS WAF logs

by centralizing them
into Amazon Security Lake

and analyzing your multi
account and multi-region
WAF traffic using AWS analytics tools

such as Amazon Athena
and Amazon QuickSight.

Amazon Security Lake
centralizes security data

from AWS environments, SaaS
providers, on premises,

and other cloud sources
into a purpose-built
data lake stored in your account.
It simplifies log aggregation,

normalizes data into the open
cybersecurity schema framework
and allows you to analyze your data
with your preferred analytics tools.

AWS WAF is a highly
configurable and scalable
cloud-native web application firewall

that helps protect web
applications from application DDoS,

web and bot attacks by
allowing you to configure rules
that allow, block or monitor web requests
based on conditions that you define.

AWS WAF can be deployed
to protect resources

such as Amazon CloudFront,
Application Load Balancers,

Amazon API Gateway, as
well as AWS AppSync.

AWS WAF logs include
information about the traffic
that is analyzed by your web ACL,

such as the time that AWS
WAF received the request
from your AWS resource,
detailed information about the request,

and the action for the rule
that each request matched.

To monitor web traffic cross
regions and cross accounts,

and to create dashboards
from AWS WAF ACL logs
such as this one, customers normally need

to centralize their logs
in a centralized location.

There are a few ways that
this can be accomplished.

One of the easiest ways
customers can choose
to centralize their AWS WAF ACL logs

is to centralize logs
using AWS Firewall Manager

to an Amazon S3 bucket for
analysis and visualization.
The following steps are usually required.
Customers set AWS Firewall Manager

to retrieve AWS WAF ACL
logs from all accounts

in an organization to
a centralized account.

Note that AWS Firewall
Manager is region specific,

so logging cross region WAF
ACL logs requires customers

to deploy AWS Firewall
Manager in multiple regions,

create Amazon Data Firehose
in each of these regions,

and then centralize these logs
in a target Amazon S3 bucket.

Best practice includes
encrypting this bucket.

Customers need to ensure
that they have the right IAM
and Amazon S3 bucket policies

to enable them to configure
centralized logging.
Customers can then use Amazon Athena

to query these logs in
the centralized S3 bucket.
For performance and cost reasons,
customers are encouraged to partition
their AWS WAF ACL logs for queries.

This normally involves
customers having to perform

additional manual steps,
such as setting up

AWS Glue resources, including
Glue Data Catalog tables
for schema management.

Once this is done,
customers can then use tools

like Amazon QuickSight
to visualize this data.

The second option, and
the focus of this video,
is to centralize AWS WAF ACL logs
through Amazon Security Lake.

Amazon Security Lake provides
the following benefits:
enabling comprehensive cross-region

and cross-account log
aggregation and collection.

With just a few clicks, Amazon
Security Lake can be deployed

to automatically
centralize all AWS WAF logs

cross-accounts and cross-regions
into Amazon S3 buckets.

This is a significant benefit
as it streamlines the process

for cross-account and
cross-region log management.

Secondly, it reduces
the operational overhead

of creating and managing
manual data lakes.

Amazon Security Lake automatically
creates the following

resources for you:
encrypted Amazon S3 buckets

and the IAM permissions necessary
to centralize your logs.
It turns on logging in the backend
so that you no longer have to create
data pipelines manually.
It also deploys an AWS Lambda function
to perform ETL jobs on raw WAF ACL data
to the open cybersecurity schema framework

and transforms logs into
Apache Parquet format.

AWS Glue resources, such as
AWS Glue Data Catalog tables,

and AWS Lake formation tables
that contain information

about data from each
source, including schema,
partition and data location information.
Subscribers, for example, Amazon Athena,

have the option to
consume data by querying
these lake formation tables.
Amazon Security Lake has adopted
the Open Cybersecurity schema framework,

which is a standardized
and extensible schema
for cybersecurity data.

OCSF addresses the challenges
of data integration,
observability and consistency.

All AWS logs that is supported
by Amazon Security Lake,
including CloudTrail logs, VPC Flow logs,

Security Hub findings,
WAF ACL logs and many more
are automatically transformed into OCSF.

This means that customers are
able to run complex queries
across different AWS logs

without having to manually
transform the data.

For example, customers
could a query to understand

if AWS WAF has successfully
blocked a port scan attempt
from a malicious actor

through querying both
Amazon GuardDuty findings
via AWS Security hub findings
and AWS WAF ACL logs.
Amazon Security Lake also integrates

with multiple third-party
providers that send data

or receive data to or
from Amazon Security Lake
in OCSF and Apache Parquet format.

Some of these partners
can be seen on screen.

OCSF provides the ability
to standardize all logs,
regardless if it's on premise, AWS logs,

SaaS application logs or other
clouds to allow customers

to enhance visibility across
all tools and environments,
accelerate threat detection and response
and streamline security operations.

AWS WAF logs are typically
of voluminous log source.

Many customers don't want
to retain AWS WAF logs

in a SIEM tool long-term
due to costs associated

with storing these logs or
due to licensing concerns.
Oftentimes this could lead to blind spots
in their security analysis.

Amazon Security Lake separates
the data storage layer

from the analytics layer,
allowing customers to retain
the logs long-term in cost-effective

Apache Parquet GZIP format with
an Amazon S3 out of the box.
This delivers up to 90% compression ratio
and saves on storage costs long-term.

Customers can use their
preferred analytics tools
to query and analyze this data.
For example, you can use Amazon Athena

or other supported partners
to perform query in place,

or federated search
and analytics to reduce

data transfer out costs
from your Security Lake.

Normal best practices for
cost optimization on S3,

such as applying S3
Lifecycle management rules

can also be applied to
further optimize costs.

Integrating AWS WAF ACL logs
with Amazon Security Lake

is simple and can be done
with just a few clicks.
Let me show you how.

This demo assumes that
you have already created
the necessary IAM permissions

and assigned a delegated
administrator for your organization
for Amazon Security Lake.

A guide to get started
with Amazon Security Lake

will be provided in the
description of this video.
To enable AWS WAF logs integration,
head to the Amazon Security Lake console.
Amazon Security Lake allows you to ingest

the AWS default sources or
ingest specific AWS sources.
In this example, I will select AWS WAF.

Next, Amazon Security Lake
allows you to ingest data
from selected regions.

You can choose to ingest logs
form all supported regions
or only specific regions.

In this example, I will select
us-east-1 and us-west-2.
You can then select which accounts

you would like to
collect AWS WAF logs for.

You can specify all accounts
in your AWS organization,
specific accounts in your organization,
or only a single account.
You can also allow Amazon Security Lake

to enable Security Lake for
new organization accounts.
This means that whenever an AWS account
is added to your organization,

Amazon Security Lake will
automatically enables

the collection of AWS WAF
ACL logs in the regions
and accounts that you have chosen.
Next, you can choose to aggregate data

from contributing regions
to a single region
for data residency requirements,

as well as select storage
classes for cost optimization.

In this demo, I will select
my contributing region

to be us-west-2 and my roll-up
region to be us-east-1.

You can transition your
logs to a lower-cost
S3 storage class for cost optimization.

For example, you can
choose to send all log data
to S3 Intelligent-Tiering after 90 days,
send logs to Glacier Deep Archive,
or expire the logs after a certain period.
When I click Create, Amazon Security Lake
begins creating all resources necessary

to centralize AWS WAF logs
into Amazon S3 buckets
that customers fully own and control.

Now that my AWS WAF ACL
logs are centralized,

I can use Amazon Athena
to easily run queries
on my Glue Data Catalog tables,

such as this query that allows
me to find denied requests

for AWS credentials over
the past seven days.

I can then further investigate
the results of this query

to understand whether this
activity is unauthorized
or if there are issues with my application
that need troubleshooting.
I can also visualize my AWS WAF ACL data

by creating a dashboard
using Amazon QuickSight.
A link to a blog post on how to visualize

Amazon Security Lake findings
with Amazon QuickSight

will be posted in the
description of this video.
In this example, I have stood up

an Amazon QuickSight
dashboard that shows me
web traffic across all of my AWS accounts
in my AWS organization.

I have created examples
that look at top rules
blocked by account ID,

requests terminated by AWS
managed rule groups over time,

top 10 allowed IP addresses,
top 10 blocked IP addresses,

top denied and allowed source
IP addresses by country,

top URLs blocked by AWS
managed rule groups,
and top URIs accessed.
This current view shows me all web traffic
across my AWS accounts in my organization.
As Amazon Security Lake centralizes
all AWS WAF ACL logs in my account,
I can now also drill down per account ID

to understand my web
traffic in a single account.

For example, this
visualization now shows me

the same dashboards but
for a single account.

This allows both network
and security teams

to derive security insights
across their organization

without the challenge
of siloed visibility.
Amazon QuickSight can also create insights
such as this ML-powered anomaly insight.
For example, I can see that an anomaly

was detected on July
27th, 2024 at 3:00 AM,
primarily driven by a higher-than-expected
hourly total count of blocked records

for the AWS Managed Rule
group for known bad inputs

and the AWS Managed Rule
Group for the Linux rule set.
I can then run further analysis
to understand the root cause.
With Amazon Security Lake,

customers benefit from
optimized log retention,
manage data lifecycle policies,

reduce time taken to
manage data pipelines,
deriving faster insights,
and simplifying security operations.

Centralizing AWS WAF logs
with Amazon Security Lake
allows customers to create multi-account
and multi-region dashboards
for comprehensive web traffic analysis.

Customers can try Amazon
Security Lake for 15 days
at no cost with any new AWS account.

If you would like to learn more
about what was shared today,
contact your AWS account team,

or engage a security specialist
by emailing us directly
at aws-detection-and-response@amazon.com.

Try Amazon Security Lake for
free in your account today.
Thank you for watching.
